titleStmt.title: Theodoret of Cyrrhus, Commentary on Daniel 9.1484.2-26
Caesarea Maritima: A Collection of Testimonia

publicationStmt.authority: Caesarea City and Port Exploration Project

editorialDecl.p: Authors of testimonia are identified with URIs from The Virtual International Authority File, see http://viaf.org. When multiple VIAF URIs exist, preference has been given to VIAF record linked to the Library of Congress authority file.
Geographic locations are identified with URIs from Pleiades: A Gazetteer of Past Places, see https://pleiades.stoa.org/docs.

When possible, textual works have been cited using URNs according to the Distributed Text Services (DTS) system, see https://distributed-text-services.github.io/specifications. Additional identifiers have been adopted from the systems used by the Perseus Digital Library (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper), Syriaca.org (http://syriaca.org), and other relevant authority systems such as WorldCat Identities or OCLC numbers (https://www.worldcat.org).
Bibliographic items are identified by a unique Caesarea-Maritima.org URI, which is linked, when possible, to OCLC numbers and other identifiers.
Dates have been encoded following the ISO 8601 standard, https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html, and the best practices established for the Srophé App, see http://srophe.app.

Languages have been encoded using ISO 639-1 (https://www.iso.org/standard/22109.html), 639-2 (https://www.iso.org/standard/4767.html), and 639-3 (https://www.iso.org/standard/39534.html) codes, following best practices of the TEI guidelines, see https://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/index.html.

taxonomy.desc:
Caesarea-Maritima.org Chronology: This chronology is adapted from the chronology used in The New Encyclopedia of Archaeological Excavations in the Holy Land
. This taxonomy is used in the catRef encoding to classify the testimonia according to the time period(s) of the events described, rather than the date of composition of the testimonium. For example, Josephus may describe events occuring well before the period of his writing.
Caesarea-Maritima.org Testimonia Typology: This typology defines three subsets of testimonia employed by the project and is used in the catRef below to further categorize a given testimonia record.

category.catDesc: A "direct testimonium" contains a word or phrase that is a direct reference to, or name for, the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. When a "direct testimonium" also contains indirect references, the classification by type is nevertheless marked only as "direct".

An "indirect testimonium" makes only an indirect reference to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. This indirect reference may take the form of a common noun or may be implied by context.

A "toponymic testimonium" contains a toponymic epithet related to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs. When a "direct testimonium" also contain a "toponymic testimonium", the testimonium is marked as belonging to both types. These two types do not always overlap and thus our data set also includes "toponymic testimonia" which are not "direct testimonia".

taxonomy.desc: The Caesarea-Maritima.org Language Usage taxonomy describes how language codes applied to individual testimonia records should be interpreted. These are used in the ana attributes in the elements found in the langUsage.

category.catDesc: The original language of a testimonia's composition, which may differ from the linguistic expression recorded in the testimonia record. For example, Severus of Antioch's Letters were originally composed in Greek but survive only in an ancient Syriac translation. The testimonia representing the Syriac version of Severus's Letters would use this category to record the original language, Greek

The linguistic expression recorded in this particular testimonia record, which may differ from the original language of composition. For example, Severus of Antioch's Letters were originally composed in Greek but survive only in an ancient Syriac translation. The testimonia representing the Syriac version of Severus's Letters would use this category to record the language, Syriac

profileDesc.creation: This entry is taken from Commentary on Daniel 9.1484.2-26 written by Theodoret of Cyrrhus in ca. 433 C.E.. This work was likely written in Cyrrhus.

body.desc: Καισάρειαν, and Caesarea are directly attested at Theodoret of Cyrrhus, Commentary on Daniel 9.1484.2-26. This passage was written ca. ca. 433 C.E. possibly in Cyrrhus.

Theodoret served as bishop of Cyrrhus in northwestern Syria in 423-457 C.E. Following his wide education in both the Christian and the Greek traditions and a brief monastic devotion, he became a vigorous leader of his diocese, distinguished by his philanthropy, and a prominent theologian, particularly in opposition to Cyril of Alexandria as a persistent defender of Nestorius. He was a prolific writer, and his many extant works include exegesis, ecclesiastical history, and Christological treatises. The earliest of his commentaries on the prophets was the Daniel. In this passage he interprets Gabriel’s prophecy of the 70 weeks as foretelling the events of Christ and the apostles, who first traveled out from Jerusalem to the cities of Judaea, including Caesarea.
body.ab:
Περὶ τὰ τρία ἔτη καὶ ἥμισυ κηρύξας ὁ Κύριος, καὶ τοὺς ἁγίους αὑτοῦ μαθητὰς τῇ διδασκαλίᾳ καὶ τοῖς θαύμασι βεβαιώσας, τότε τὸ πάθος ὑπέμεινε· μετὰ δὲ τὸν σταυρὸν καὶ τὸν θάνατον, καὶ τὴν ἀνάστασιν, καὶ τὴν εἰς οὐρανοὺς ἀνάβασιν, καὶ τὴν τοῦ ἁγίου Πνεύματος ἐπιφοίτησιν, τὸν λοιπὸν τῆς ἑβδομάδος χρόνον οἱ ἅγιοι ἀπόστολοι ἐν Ἱεροσολύμοις κηρύττοντές τε καὶ θαυματουργοῦντες, πολλάς τε ἀνθρώπων χιλιάδας εἰς τὴν εὐαγγελικὴν ποδηγήσαντες διδασκαλίαν, τῆς Νέας Διαθήκης ἠξίωσαν καὶ τῆς τοῦ παναγίου βαπτίσματος χάριτος τυχεῖν παρεσκεύασαν. Εἶτα τῶν κατὰ τὸν ἅγιον Στέφανον ὑπὸ τῶν Ἰουδαίων τολμηθέντων, διεσπάρησαν μὲν οἱ ἄλλοι κατὰ τὰς πόλεις τῆς Ἰουδαίας, οἱ δὲ θεῖοι ἀπόστολοι σμικρὸν ἐν Ἱεροσολύμοις διατρίψαντες χρόνον, εἰς τὴν Σαμάρειαν καὶ Καισάρειαν, Λύδδαν τε καὶ Ἰώππην περιιόντες, ἅπασιν ἀνθρώποις τὰ σωτήρια δόγματα προσφέρειν ἠπείγοντο. Τούτου χάριν ὁ θεῖος ἀρχάγγελος τῷ μακαρίῳ φησὶ Δανιὴλ, ὅτι Δυναμώσει διαθήκην πολλοῖς ἑβδομὰς μία, τόν τε πρὸ τοῦ σταυροῦ τοῦ Κυρίου χρόνον, καὶ τὸν μετὰ τὴν ἀνάστασιν τοῦ Σωτῆρος τῶν ἁγίων ἀποστόλων ἐν Ἱεροσολύμοις διδασκαλίαν κατὰ ταὐτὸν συναγαγών.
Ed. Schulze and Migne 1864

When the Lord had preached for around three and a half years, and after he had confirmed his holy disciples through teaching and miracles, he then endured the passion. After the cross and death, the resurrection, the ascent into heaven, and the coming of the Holy Spirit, the holy apostles were preaching and performing miracles for the remainder of the week in Jerusalem, and after leading many thousand men to the teaching of the Gospels, they imparted the New Testament and prepared them to obtain the grace of all-holy baptism. Then, when the Jews took acted boldly against St. Stephan, while the others were scattered to the cities of Judaea, the divine apostles stayed for a short time in Jerusalem, visiting Samaria and Caesarea, Lydda and Joppa, and they pressed on with offering the doctrines of salvation to all people. For this reason the divine archangel said to the blessed Daniel, “One week will confirm a convenant for many people,” including as one both the period before the crucifixion of the Lord and the period of the holy apostles teaching in Jerusalem after the resurrection.
Revised from Hill 2006
